bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Laura Armistead Carter, August 27, 1928

div1.p: LePrince responds to Carter's request for verification of various references.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Laura Armistead Carter, August 27, 1928
div1.opener:
Book,
Bib.
LePrince
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
ROOM 118, COURTHOUSE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
August 27, 1928.
Miss Laura Carter,
The Westmoreland,
2122 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received your
letter of enquiry and wish I could be of more use
to you but I have very little knowledge of the infor-
mation requested.

With regard to larvae of Aedes
aegypti in street gutters you will find the following
in “Mosquito Control in Panama,” by J. A. LePrince and
A. J. Orenstein, G. P. Putnams Sons, New York, 1916.

Page 55. “If containers are upset or their contents
enter into a pond or ditch, the larvae of
Aedes calopus will develop to maturity.;” O.K

And on Page 240. “As a matter of fact, we occasionally
found“find” a few larvae in streams and ditches, O.K
but it was not known at that time that they
had been washed out of containers.”
book says:- tho “found” is better L.A.C.

With regard to Dr. Finlay's
data and that of Taylor, possibly Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
142-148 Calle K, Vedado, Havana, Cuba, may be able to
give you the data you wish.

Dr. M. A. Barber's present
address is % Dr. C. W. Gerber, Las Cruces, New Mexico.

I am sorry I can not tell you
where the report of the breeding of Aedes aegypti in
winter was published, but it took place at Carbondale,
Illinois, at the hotel opposite the Illinois Central Rail-
way Depot and Mr. Ferguson, State Sanitary Engineer of
-2-
Illinois was the person bitten. It was about 1922. I
was with him at the time and I got the second one that
went for him.

With regard to Sir. Rubert W.
Boyce, in his book “Yellow Fever and Its Prevention”
published by E. P. Dutton and Company, New York, 1911, ✓?//G
on Page 275 it is stated with regard to stegomyia:
“When once the mosquito is infected, all evidence points
to the fact that it retains the infection for a long
period; three months have been noted, but it is quite
possible that the infection lasts as long as the life
of the mosquito, etc.”

I can not state that the above
extracts are those which are specifically referred to,
but they are pretty close.

It may be that I referred to
the Havana work in some discussions at the Southern
Medical Association, but I do not remember.
div1.closer:
With best wishes,
Sincerely yours, J. A. LePrince J. A. LePrince.
LeP:LC
